title: London Hedge Fund Foretelus Capital Fonejacked for $1.1 mln
text:
London Hedge Fund Foretelus Capital Fonejacked for $1.1 mln London Hedge Fund Foretelus Capital Fonejacked for $1.1 mln The Chief Financial Officer of the firm got an alarming call on a Friday afternoon from an individual claiming to be a bank representative Advertising Print This Post 
A court filing details a case of stolen funds from a hedge fund in London by a cleverly disguised phone jacker. On a late Friday afternoon in 2013, when the Chief Financial Officer (CFO) of London based hedge fund Fortelus Capital Management picked up the phone to answer a call he had no suspicions about the malicious intent of the caller on the other end of the line. 
The individual claimed to be representing the company’s bank Coutts. Without questioning the identity of the caller, the CFO replied to the request to generate some codes for the individual on the other end of the phone line to allegedly cancel 15 payments which were deemed suspicious by the “bank”. 
the firm’s books parted with £742,668 
The phone jacker claimed that there is suspicious activity on the account, which was enough for the CFO Thomas Meston to share the confidential data with the other end of the line. 
Logging into the company’s bank account on the next Monday has revealed a disaster was in the making on Friday afternoon. The firm’s books parted with £742,668 ($1.14 million) which went missing from the Coutts bank account. 
There was no recordings of any bank employee calling the office of Fortelus Capital Management on that Friday. 
The hedge fund terminated the CFO immediately and is currently in the process of taking legal action against Mr Meston. According to the court documentation which is publicly available the defendant is pleading not guilty and argues that there was no negligence conducted on his part. 
the former CFO of the hedge fund has given up his bonus checks and salary totaling to £136,600 
The lawyers of Fortelus have stressed that client funds remained unscathed by the major security breach. the firm has aimed to reassure its investors that the occurrence was due to human error and steps have been taken by Fortelus to ensure the safety of the firm’s capital. 
The innocence of Mr Meston is yet to be proven in court, but according to his defense he has acted in good faith and did not realize that he was giving out sensitive information over the phone. 
The case made by the lawyer of Meston is that the CFO is not personally liable with his own assets to cover for the funds stolen from Foretells Capital Management. 
According to the court documents as a consequence of his actions, the former CFO of the hedge fund has given up his bonus checks and salary totaling to £136,600 ($210,000). Got a news tip? Let Us Know FOUND A MISTAKE
